general_texts:
Students graduating from Sacramento State are required to complete a second semester composition course. Second semester composition courses (ENGL 20, ENGL 20M, or an approved equivalent) must be completed with a grade of C- or better.


Although not required for admission, transfer students are encouraged to complete a course fulfilling this requirement prior to transfer. Please see a counselor for more information.

general_texts:
Thank you for your interest in Sacramento State!


This articulation agreement displays the lower-division courses required in the major: Sacramento State courses on the left and approved (articulated) transfer courses on the right. Although completion of the coursework listed below is not mandatory prior to admission, students are advised to complete as much lower-division course preparation as possible prior to transfer.


Additional Resources:

  • See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major.
  • Visit our Sac State Apply page for more information about our campus!
  • Visit the Admissions website for current transfer admission requirements.
  • Connect with an Admissions Counselor.

1. Students must earn a "C-" grade or higher in all courses required in the major.
  2. The Associate Degree for Transfer (ADT) in Anthropology is compatible with the B.A. in Anthropology - Archaeology and Biological Anthropology concentration at Sacramento State. Students pursuing the Associates Degree for Transfer must complete all lower-division major coursework with a "C" or better.
  3. ANTH 1A, Physical Anthropology Lab, must be taken concurrently, or following ANTH 1.
  4. For additional information, please visit: Department of Anthropology.

1. Students must earn a "C" grade or higher in all courses applied to the Art History major.
  2. Additional Art History requirement: Select one lower-division course from Photography or Art Studio in a medium other than drawing.
  3. The Associate Degree for Transfer (ADT) in Art History is compatible with the B.A. in Art History at Sacramento State. Students pursuing the Associate Degree for Transfer must complete all lower-division major coursework with a "C" or better.
  4. All lower-division core requirements in Art History must be completed prior to enrollment in upper-division courses at Sacramento State.
  5. Art History students are required to meet the Sacramento State Foreign Language Requirement by completing the second semester (1B) of a college-level foreign language course with a grade of C- or better (or equivalent foreign language study, as described in the current University catalog). Students who plan to pursue further graduate study in art history are encouraged to learn a foreign language relevant to their art historical interests through the second semester intermediate level (2B).
  6. For additional information, please visit: Department of Art.

  • Visit our Sac State Apply page for more information about our campus!
  • Visit the Admissions website for current transfer admission requirements.
  • Connect with an Admissions Counselor.

1. Students must earn a "C-" grade or higher in all courses and prerequisite courses required in the major, with the exception of CHEM 1A, which requires a "C" grade or higher.
  2. Students pursuing a Chemistry degree are strongly encouraged to complete as much of the lower-division science and math curriculum as possible. In particular, the department advises Chemistry majors to complete: CHEM 1A, CHEM 1B, MATH 30, MATH 31, PHYS 5A, and PHYS 5B (or PHYS 11A, PHYS 11B, and PHYS 11C) prior to transfer.
  3. Students are strongly advised to complete Calculus and Physics prior to transfer as these courses are prerequisites to Physical Chemistry (a required upper-division course for all Chemistry majors).
  4. Students pursuing the B.S. in Biochemistry should complete courses equivalent to BIO 1 and 2 prior to transfer.
  5. English 20, or an approved second semester composition course, is a prerequisite for all upper-division laboratories. It is recommended students complete this course prior to transfer.
  6. Foreign Language Graduation Requirement Exemption: Students graduating with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Biochemistry will not be subject to the Universitys Foreign Language Graduation Requirement. Students who change major may be subject to the Universitys Foreign Language Graduation Requirement.
  7. For additional information, please visit: Department of Chemistry.

Thank you for your interest in Sacramento State!


This articulation agreement displays the lower-division courses required in the major: Sacramento State courses on the left and approved (articulated) transfer courses on the right. Students are advised to complete the lower-division coursework in this agreement prior to transfer.


Additional Resources:

  • See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major.
  • Visit our Sac State Apply page for more information about our campus!
  • Visit the Admissions website for current transfer admission requirements.
  • Connect with an Admissions Counselor.

1. All undergraduate programs within the College of Business have officially been designated as impacted. Students interested in becoming Business Administration majors must complete a supplemental application to the major and complete the following prerequisite requirements: ACCY 1, ACCY 2, ECON 1A, ECON 1B, MATH 24, MGMT 10, MIS 10, and STAT 1. All prerequisite courses must be completed with a minimum "C-" grade or higher, with the exception of MATH 24, which requires a minimum grade of "C" or better.
  2. All pre-majors must demonstrate spreadsheet competency by completing MIS 10.
  3. MATH 24 requires a minimum grade of "C" or better. AP Calculus with a score of 3 or above or any college-level Calculus course (NOT Pre-Calculus) will be accepted in lieu of MATH 24.
  4. Foreign Language Graduation Requirement Exemption: Students graduating with a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration (all concentrations) will not be subject to the University's Foreign Language Graduation Requirement. Students who change major may be subject to the University's Foreign Language Graduation Requirement.
  5. For information on the COB's Academic Policies (including grading and repeat policies), please visit: COB Academic Policies.
  6. For information on the COB's Program requirements, please visit: COB Program Requirements.
  7. For additional information, please visit: College of Business.

1. The Communication Sciences and Disorders program is organized for students to begin in the Fall semester. If students begin in the Spring, it will take an extra semester to finish the undergraduate curriculum.
  2. Students must have a 2.5 GPA in the major in order to graduate with a B.S. in Communication Sciences and Disorders.
  3. Students are strongly advised to complete all undergraduate General Education units before beginning major coursework.
  4. It is strongly recommended students complete a course in Physics and/or Chemistry as some programs offering the Master's Degree in Speech Language Pathology or Communication Sciences and Disorders will require it.
  5. In lieu of CHDV 30, CSAD will approve any other course in Human Development or Developmental Psychology across the Lifespan (birth through death must be covered).
  6. In lieu of DEAF 51, CSAD will approve any course in Sign Language.
  7. In lieu of PSYC 2, CSAD will approve any Introductory Psychology course.
  8. In lieu of STAT 1, CSAD will accept a course in Introductory Statistics.
  9. For additional information, please visit: Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

Completion of the degree meets the single subject content requirement for a subsequent teaching credential with a waiver of the CSET (California Subject Examinations for Teachers). For students who want to earn their teaching credential from Sacramento State, it is possible to finish the prerequisite courses while completing this degree to avoid additional out of pocket tuition and fees. 1. Students must earn a minimum grade of "C-" or higher in all courses required in the major. A minimum 2.00 GPA is required in each area. To enter a California credential program, a minimum GPA of 2.67 is required by the time of application to a California teaching credential program. Students are encouraged not to petition for CR/NR or P/NP grading option in Liberal Studies courses taken at the community college.
  2. In addition to the admission requirements for the university, transfer students are strongly encouraged to complete the majority of the courses listed in this articulation agreement including upper-division course options when possible and foreign language, if necessary. The more requirements completed prior to transfer translates to fewer requirements to complete after transfer. Please visit the Liberal Studies website for additional information on course substitutions and options for upper-division courses not listed on this agreement.
  3. The Liberal Studies Program satisfies Sacramento State General Education requirements. Students intending to transfer as Liberal Studies majors should not follow a CSU General Education or IGETC plan but instead follow the Liberal Studies articulation for their community college. Consult with a Liberal Studies advisor for the possibility of course substitutions for previously completed coursework or for courses that are not articulated. Only a Liberal Studies advisor is authorized to provide substitutions for the courses in the agreement below.
  4. Students with catalog rights Fall 2025 or later should complete a course that satisfies CSU GE Area 6 (Ethnic Studies). Cal-GETC Area 6 (Ethnic Studies) courses also satisfy this requirement.
  5. For the most current major information, visit the Liberal Studies website.

1. The traditional pre-licensure Nursing program at Sacramento State is one of the most highly sought after programs in Northern California. Due to the large number of applications, the program is officially impacted. Up to 80 traditional pre-licensure students are admitted to the clinical portion of the baccalaureate Nursing program each semester. A competitive selection process has been established since applications exceed program space in the traditional pre-licensure program.
  2. The Nursing program is open only to those who can satisfy the California residence requirements. Students who qualify for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) status, AB 540 status, or military fee waiver are eligible.
  3. Students must complete a two-semester Anatomy and Physiology series with an in-class lab.
  4. The prerequisite requirement in Chemistry may be met with any college-level general or inorganic or organic or integrated course (with associated lab if required at the institution where the course was taken; otherwise not required). An overview or preparatory course for college-level Chemistry is not acceptable.
  5. One non-science and one science prerequisite course, two total, may be in progress at the time of application.
  6. Completion of the TEAS is required for all students applying to the nursing program. A minimum score of 75% is required to apply.
  7. Students are strongly encouraged to complete the co-requisite courses prior to admission to the clinical program. Introductory Psychology, Nutrition, and Life Span Human Development must be completed prior to the second semester of the nursing program. A societal-cultural patterns course must be completed prior to licensure and graduation.
  8. Students are strongly encouraged to attend a group advising session for additional information on the application process and selection criteria.
  9. Please consult the California State University, Sacramento Catalog and School of Nursing website for a complete explanation of all requirements and deadlines.

1. The concentration in General Philosophy requires 18 units of elective courses. The majority of the elective courses are upper-division and must be taken at Sacramento State after transfer. PHIL 61 is the only lower-division elective that may be completed prior to transfer.
  2. The Associate Degree for Transfer (ADT) in Philosophy is compatible with the B.A. in Philosophy at Sacramento State. Students pursuing the Associate Degree for Transfer must complete all lower-division major coursework with a "C" or better.
  3. Students may complete PHIL 4 to meet CSU GE Area 1B (Critical Thinking).
  4. Students may complete PHIL 2, PHIL 6, or PHIL 26 to meet CSU GE Area 3B (Humanities).
  5. The minor in Philosophy requires 18 semester units. At least 9 units must be upper-division Philosophy courses. The lower-division Philosophy courses may overlap with general education requirements. Students may select up to 9 units of lower-division Philosophy courses from the following: PHIL 2, PHIL 4, PHIL 6, PHIL 26, PHIL 60, or PHIL 61. Please see an advisor for details.
  6. For additional information, please visit: Department of Philosophy.

1. Students must earn a "C-" grade or higher in all courses applied to the major.
  2. Recreation Therapy students should also plan to complete 3 units each in the following: 1) Abnormal Psychology, 2) Lifespan Human Development, and 3) Human Anatomy/Human Physiology for certification. Please contact Dr. Jamie Hoffman, Recreation Therapy Advisor, at (916) 278-5021 or via email at jamie.hoffman@csus.edu to discuss possible courses that may be completed at your college. An advisor approval is required to assure compliance with certification requirements.
  3. Foreign Language Graduation Requirement Exemption: Students graduating with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Recreation Therapy will not be subject to the Universitys Foreign Language Graduation Requirement. Students who change major may be subject to the Universitys Foreign Language Graduation Requirement.
  4. For additional information, please visit: Department of Health Science.

1. Students must earn a "C-" grade or higher in all courses required in the major.
  2. Students must select one course (from any major) that focuses on race and ethnic relations in the United States. The course may be either a comparative survey course, or a course that focuses specifically on African Americans, Asian Americans, Chicano/Latino Americans, or Native Americans.
  3. Courses in Western Civilization are not acceptable for meeting the World Civilization requirements for Social Science Majors.
  4. A combined Introduction to Macro/Micro Economics course is acceptable for Social Science Majors.
  5. Overlap between the Social Science Major and General Education is unrestricted, except for History courses. Only 6 units of History can be used for G.E.
  6. The Associate Degree for Transfer (ADT) in Social Justice Studies is compatible with the B.A. in Social Sciences at Sacramento State. Students pursuing the Associate Degree for Transfer must complete all lower-division major coursework with a "C" or better.
  7. For more information, please visit the Social Science Program page.
